item.title: “He’s gone from coercion...to punishment. I think he thinks, at this point now, if he can’t get Ukraine, he’s pretty much going to destroy it.” Foreign-affairs specialist Fiona Hill assesses Vladimir Putin’s motivations in Ukraine, on “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/UnOuRbZIAb https://t.co/292xPIbpBs
The sight of Russia’s central bank being hit so hard by sanctions no one expected will lead China to increase its efforts to establish the yuan as a reserve currency https://t.co/98UajDHVmf

“The West allowed [Vladimir] Putin’s people to keep their fortunes in Western banks and spend them on Western education for their kids”, as well as on “villas and penthouses in Western resorts,” writes Lithuania’s prime minister https://t.co/Nasi7Cyipo
Vladimir Putin has rattled his nuclear sabre three times in as many weeks. It seems likely he will behave in a similar way in conflicts and stand-offs to come https://t.co/7ZIs0P6KoN

Ukrainian air defences have been persistent, but the Russians were also poorly prepared for the amount of resistence they have encountered https://t.co/CS95YcwMkY
